So wait...are we supposed to ignore that the un-weighted/messed with rope oscillated - at the end - between the J shape and the straight line but "angled back" shape? Because the end was certainly moving back and forth between a slight J shape and a straight line. For the same reasons that the section above is in a straight line, because the end doesn't have more rope weighing it down, it is free to flap around in the wind behind it, making a slight J-shape.

That's the real shape it makes. Not the "straight line" answer in the video. Because physics in the real world is never perfect and there will be oscillation. The average or approximation shape is a J-Shape.

Neat!  Of course, in real life, a helo would almost never carry a cable beneath it WITHOUT some sort of 'load' (usually a heavy load) at the end of the cable.  If a helo needs to carry a long cable, it would typically be loaded within the cabin/cargo compartment, or spooled/gathered up, and slung beneath the aircraft.  [also, if you need mobility in an open helicopter (or other aircraft) cabin, you could wear a belted harness [typically called a 'gunner's belt'] where the individual is wearing a sturdy belt of nylon webbing, and that belt is anchored to a cargo tiedown (within the cabin) by a long/sturdy nylon strap--the anchoring strap being long enough for movement around the cabin.  Gaining movement--in an open aircraft--by wearing a REALLY LOOSE seatbelt is a bit dicey.]

I hate to say it, but answer B is not right. Friction is here supposed to be constant along the rope, but this is only approximately true, for shorter ropes. The lower a piece of rope hangs, the denser air gets, and thus the more friction you'll get. The lower parts will undergo more horizontal force than higher parts, causing option C to be true. But the curvature can only be seen using longer ropes, so B is "approximately" true. But since the question explicitly told us to count in air friction, C is the only right answer.

It can be very simply replicated too. Just take some sort of string and hold it in 3 different ways.
For no weight, just blow on it, and it makes it fairly straight line.
For increased resistance, simply hold the string in the middle of the path it was taking without you holding it and blow on the bottom, the bottom then curves further than the previous trajectory of just blowing on it because you're already holding the string at the trajectory it had when just blowing on it and the extra air on the string simulates increased air resistance.
Then for increased weight, simply hold both the beginning and end of the string loosely (at the angle it would have been without you holding it) and blow on the string, because the two immovable points at the top and bottom, the middle of the string will be pushed further, creating that backwards 'J' shape.

And this is just me visualizing. I wrote this all without testing it. But, just to verify, after a quick test, the results are just as I described.

Ok, so I haven't heard the answer yet, but something tells me it's the S curve. 

I just feel like the effect of air resistance won't be consistent along the length of the rope. The top of the rope is taut against the helicopter since it's anchored at the top, so the rope will be more rigid at the top, and as you go along the middle of the rope, air takes a greater effect and pushes it back. Then when you work to the bottom of the rope, there is less rope in terms of weight the farther down you go. So basically along the middle of the rope you have air and the weight of the rope below it pulling it back with the wind, but at the bottom the weight of the rope relative to its length isn't enough to pull it straight down, so it forms the S shape. 

I feel like I explained that really poorly, but it makes so much sense in my head.

I’m speechless. The examiner says “ I saw this, so it makes a great exam question!” And then sets the “right” answer based on loose observation, not detailed observations that actually consider the forces employed ( which is in effect what the exam question is asking the student). A bit like saying “ I don’t see the table bending when I put my coffee cup on it, ergo it doesn’t bend at all”, when in reality, the table does bend, but not by enough to be seen ( but it can certainly be measured). The way that this question was thought up completely negates every single precept of good experiment process and deduction that we are taught from the very first physics lesson. The observer saw a “straight rope” and assumed it straight. But it’s wasn’t actually straight! In fact, on several shots in the video, you can see that the rope certainly isn’t perfectly straight. The question should clearly state that the effect of downwash should be ignored in order for the question to be considered valid.
The question should have included that “downdraught is negligible”!

i got that answer thru a force balance at any point on the rope.  because the rope is not accelerating, the net force in the horizontal must be zero.  the horizontal force of friction must be balanced by a horizontal component of tension in the rope.  To get the  horizontal component, the rope must be hanging at an angle relative to vertical under the copter.  Because the friction force is the same along the length of the rope, the angle must be the same.  Therefore, rope is straight.  Answer B

I think the general correct answer is "C", but the experiment used a very heavy rope relative to the magnitude of air resistance; the explanation of "cutting the rope into many pieces" ignores the weight of the rope acting on each piece, which is greatest at the top of the rope and zero at the bottom - this variation in the force due to gravity will generate a curve in the rope at constant speed, which is just about demonstrated by the parachute experiment; if you look at the diagram at 5:10, and correct the downward force to be very small, then the tension force will have to be acting in the direction of travel to balance forces, meaning that diagram "C" describes the resulting curve in the rope

Before I watch:

Free body diagram on the rope
Helicopter becomes vertical and horizontal force at one end of rope: up, Fy and to the right Fx. Air resistance, becomes equal distributed force to the left across the rope: A/L l. Gravity, G is force down at center of mass in middle. Length is L
It's at constant speed so Sum(Fx)=0
Assuming the rope is straight down, and helicopter is flying right. Fy=g so vertical cancels out; sum of moments about the helicopter end = M = Fx(0) - (A/L)(L)(L/2) =/= 0 so the rope would bend, meaning it can't be straight down.
Constant speed : Fx-(A/L)(L) = 0
Fx=A
A acts at L/2 which means we have a couple force creating a clockwise moment at L/4. If it were a beam the left side would be in tension and right side would be in compression which to me would indicate that D) the inverted hook shape is the answer.

It's not force due to air resistance that is causing your effect.  Remember even the problem said to ignore that.  It's the fact the helicopter's counter force to gravity has both a horizontal and vertical component - which creates a diagonal tension as you correctly point out.  The cable is assumed to be perfectly flexible.  So each infinitesimally small component is treated as a chain link and the forces are integrated along the whole.  Also the curve shape of 'D' depends on the ratio of mass between the cable (per meter) and the weight.   It's not uniform across all masses of each.

I honestly did not find this scenario counter-intuitive at all. So long as the weight of the rope is uniformly distributed along its length, it will hang straight. If the helicopter just hovers without moving (assuming no significant wind), the rope will hang vertically downwards. If the helicopter moves at a constant velocity, the rope will align diagonally straight and if the helicopter accelerates, it will align straight along the helicopter body. The straightening is because the air resistance kind of supports the rope weight.

wrong verbage in the question relative to the experiment. a cable is stranded wire. typically they have a reinforced loop at the end. the question like more multiple choice test questions doesn't give a ton of variables and so the test taker needs to assume what principles are being tested in order to fill in the blanks. there is also wire rope, but focusing just on different cables the shape will change based on the speed, the attachment style at the end (as demonstrated by the cowbell), weight of the helicopter, and the thickness of the cable. the speed puts more force in the horizontal direction, the thickness of the cable affects the gravitational force on the cable (if it is heavy enough it will keep the line taught like in your experiments), the weight of the helicopter dictates the length and strength of the wash, and the connection type affects the downward force at the very end of the line. we could add more variables as how long it has to keep the shape or if there was any sort of forces on the line prior to the snapshot of the question. i have seen all shapes other than A. based on different variables, that makes it a bad test question.

The rope is first gonna go in a diagonal line to the left thanks to G-forces caused by acceleration. The reason it keeps hanging backwards in air is because the further down the rope you get, the lighter the force pulling the rope down will be but not air resistance. That's because it's contact area with the air does not decrease while it's weight does, linearly. That essentially means that the further down you go, the greater effect air resistance is gonna have, linearly. But when air resistance is not there, the rope will hang straight down when g-forces settle.

Assuming that the air flow from the rotor blades doesn't interact with the cable and that the horizontal air flow beneath the helicopter is constant from the top of the cable to the bottom, the shape of the cable is a straight line and the slope of the cable is given by :
α = sqrt ( (1. + sqrt (1.+4β) ) /2β) with β = (F/P)^2.
F is the force of the horizontal wind per meter (N/m) and P is the weight of the cable per meter (N/m).
As β goes to 0 (no air friction), α goes to infinity, the cable is vertical and as β goes to infinity (cable weight is negligeable), α goes to 0, the cable is horizontal.
If F/P = sqrt(2), α = 1 which is what is expected (slope of 45 degrees).



Consequently, the correct answer is diagram B which best shows the shape of the cable (CQFD)

Every part of the rope is travelling at the same speed - therefore the wind drag on every part of the rope is the same. So, at a point 1 foot below the point 1 foot above, the angle of the rope will be the same as the angle down to the next foot.

The thing is that no matter weather you put a kettlebell below or not, there is always the weight, of the rope. It is how much this weight is, what causes the how far up the curve begins along with the speed of the helicopter. Think of it this way, the topmost point is being pulled the most (because it has the entire weight of the system pulling it taut) and hence stays the most taut. The other/bottom-most point of the rope is being pulled the least (since nothing is pulling it from below), it has the most degree of freedom. Hence it gets a chance to sometimes dip towards the ground but also jump up if it gets hit with a sudden gust of wind. In fact we do see the rope wobbling the most at the bottom most point. We also see the same behavior even with the weight attached ! Even with the weight, when the helicopter starts, the rope is straight at the beginning, but as the heli moves forward it pulls the rope closest to it more than the bottom part (because nothing is pullingthe rope at an angle at the bottom-most part) and the initial curve is formed. At 7:30 you can observe that when either the speed of the aircraft increases the tautness of the rope changes and it starts from the top and that wave makes it to the bottom of the rope. My guess is that if a floating balloon is tied to the end of the rope instead of the weight to reverse the effect we would see the same effect inverted i.e. a "J shape", the curve of which would depend on how much does weight the baloon can carry up. Moreover, it would also be the most bouncy or least taut part of the rope.

I don't think the analysis in the video is quite complete (and it is circular). The pressure on each rope segment due to air resistance depends on the angle of the rope segment with respect to the airflow. If the rope forms a straight line, then the total force due to air resistance on the end segment of length $L$ increases linearly with $L$ (as stated in the video), but without knowing in advance that this is true we cannot deduce that the functional dependence on $L$ isn't more complicated. The analysis in the video does show that answer (B) is, in some appropriate sense, self-consistent, but plenty of self-consistent solutions to Newton's equations are not seen in nature (e.g. unstable solutions). I think answer (B) is the unique solution and is in fact stable (and you can see this by looking at how the rope would move when curved).

Same air resistance at every point? I think for a considerably long rope, the difference in air density between the top and the bottom of the rope is not negligible. So is the difference in drag. This creates a shift in the aerodynamic center on the rope, with the bias towards the bottom. There always exists a moment that tries to turn the rope due to the eccentricity between the center of gravity and the aerodynamic center. Hence C would be the right choice if the altitude was higher (as everybody's intuition suggested). The same effect can be observed if the area of the rope or the velocity of helicopter is high.

This question is garbage as an exam question. It is more of a hypothesis rather than a straight answer. Even though drag is negligible, weight is not mentioned and it could easily be assumed that the weight of the rope would have an impact. Also, people have no idea of how powerful a total rotor thrust of a helicopter can interfere with the rope. Yes, they did say that the rope was perfectly flexible but you are not being told the forces that act on it and to what extent, and this is why we have experiments, because we can never truly know. This question is pure exam technique and has nothing to do with intuition or knowledge, it is something that you simply see over and over again and memorise the answer. It is an incredibly interesting phenomenon, and I love it, and I love the experiment but it is definitely not an exam question. The only way this would be viable as an exam question is if you could choose the option and explain in physics terms what made you think this was the answer.

I stopped at 0:34 and don't want to watch the end, because the question does not have enough info. If it's high school physics, the answer is B: each dx of rope is submitted to longitudinal tension, gravity and air friction. At constant speed, etc., air friction plus gravity sum up to the same vector all along, just as if gravity was a non-vertical force. Hence the rope hangs like it would at rest. B. To get any other answer you'd have to take into account a non-homogenous air flow around the copter, due to both the aerodynamics of the copter and the air flow of the blades, which we don't have any info on. However that would be the real answer.

I think the easiest, most elementary explanation is weight distribution. Because there are only two constant forces acting on the rope, and air isn’t changing, weight distribution will determine the position of the rope. And since with no weight added the distribution will be the same, so the rope will be a straight line. However, with added weight, the weight distribution changes, and gravity is taking more of an effect on the bottom, so the bottom will be more vertical than the top. And when a parachute is added, it will be more horizontal because of more air resistance on the bottom.

This is kind of a poorly-written physics problem. There's no inherent physical reason to discount the rotor wash as a factor in the dynamics. It's only the specific elements Derek chose to test with that make it appear negligible. A heavier helicopter (that requires greater downforce to remain aloft) paired with a less massive rope would behave differently to the naked eye.

In fact, I would argue that, because the problem as written specifically indicates that air resistance is NON-negligible, the curved diagram actually best represents the state of the rope in the experiment more accurately than the straight diagonal one. There IS a curve there. It just happens to be too small to see.

My guess for why people (myself included) think C is correct with no weight, is because most people are exposed to an antenna on a car making that shape. However, it only does so because it has a rigid body and isn’t perfectly flexible especially at its attachment point.

i think the conclusions are incorrect. a weight on a rope would produce bouncing behavior on the rope as the rope begin to oscillate. that is what generate the jerky movement. a rope have more weight itself at the bottom than the top. take a pile of pancakes and look if the one at the bottom is more flat than the one at the top. that is exactly what happens to the rope. the tension on the rope is the greatest at the top of the rope. just take a toy spring rainbow spring and hang it and you will see that the tension is the highest at the top. the symmetric motion is due to equal air resistance.and gradual tension increase from bottom to top of the rope. a weight would produce a higher air resistance and produce greater tension on the rope where the force transfer unevently.

I was thinking either D, or E, so i'm curious to find out.
I thought D because i thought the wind speed will push the rope back, but the rope itself "wants" to stay straight, and so the wind curves across the length of the rope, with the lower end moving slightly inwards, that is, if it doesn't sweep all the way to the back and gets stuck in the back.
And i thought E because of similar reasons, but also considering some kind of airpocket underneath the helicopter, because of aerodynamic reasons, or the main rotor causing some bubble, which would cause the upper part of the rope to be fairly unaffected by the wind speed, but the lower part will swing out from the winds, but still curves back to its preferred straight state, again, that is, if it doesn't sweep all the way to the back and kills everyone.

EDIT: Damn, B was the one i least expected, i dismissed that one as "that's what it looks like if you hang a metal pole from the heli".
Also, why i didn't think it was A, well.. it's kinda obvious, unless the wind is blowing from the back and matches the speed of the heli, otherwise it just wouldn't be possible.
And why i didn't think it was C, because i didn't think the rope would be light enough to swing like that, that is, of course, if it doesn't just swing all the way back and .. well you catch my drift.

But yeah, did not expect B, but now that i see it, it makes sense at low speeds, i guess i was just imagining higher speeds, unless that is also what it looks like at high speeds.

Since the instructions never mention forward movement, only "horizontal", and the other mention of movement is "to the right", then I have to assume the vehicle is moving sideways ("strafing") to the right, ie. there's no forward component of it's "horizontal" movement.

Therefore the observer "to the right" (to the vehicle's right) would see the cable as "straight" because the vehicle is moving straight toward the observer, so the observer wouldn't see any curves in the cable (except for momentary ripples due to turbulence?).

But the question never specifies whether our task is to describe the "shape of the cable" from the suggested POV (to the vehicle's right) or just to guess if it "curves" in a general (POV-independent) sense...

Finally, IF downwash is a factor in the cable's shape, and since higher velocities are used to help helis outrun their downwash (aka ETL?), wouldn't speed matter? Wouldn't 0.01 kph result in a different shape (POV-independent) from 60 kph?

Likewise with the density of the rope? The denser it is, the less observable any curve due to air flow?

The shape of the rope will be largely influenced by the cross section of the rope versus its density. If the rope has zero cross-section, then it will have zero drag and its shape will be determined by only two things: the weight of the weight on the end and the drag of the weight on the end, but it will be a diagonal line. If it has zero weight and any drag, and no weight on the end, it will be a flow line of the air streaming past the helicopter. Other than those two, it is a balance between the mass and drag of the rope and the weight, which is infinitely variable. Try it with a 200 pound weight. You will see that the behavior is different, with the same rope, from a 20 pound weight.

I called B for the question and was glad I got it right but I’m gonna type out my reasoning here:

Aerodynamic drag only depends on the dynamic pressure (which depends on air density and free stream velocity), the drag coefficient of said surface (which depends on surface roughness, shape, etc.), and the total surface area in contact with the flow of the air (typically in aerospace, this is just a wing area). Since we can assume that for every small rope section the dynamic pressure, drag coefficient, and the associated small amount surface area with said section is the same for the entire rope, the force of drag is therefore constant across the entire rope. This leads to the conclusion that the force of gravity (weight) and/or tension must be the shape-determining forces.
Looking at gravity, each small section of rope must have the same exact weight because it is all made of the same material, so the shape-determinant isn’t gravity (in the non-weighted scenario at least). So tension must determine the shape.
From here, you can realize that for the rope to be in equilibrium (or not flying away) in respect to an inertial frame of reference moving with the helicopter, the force of tension has to equal the sum of the force of drag and gravity together. Since these two forces are normal to one another, tension must be diagonal to fully equalize each component. Ok, so we now know it’s not just some straight like downwards or somehow diagonally forwards, but does the rope curve at all? Well, as with all tension forces, it acts in both directions. Because it’s a rope and cannot sustain large compressive forces, at the very top of the rope attached to the helicopter, the force of tension pulling up-right is the greatest since the force of the rest of the rope is adding a separate tension down-left. As you gown down the rope, the up-right tension decreases just as the down-left tension also decreases. Since each rope section has the same drag and weight, this decrease in both tensions is linear, thus, you get a straight line.

The angle at which any section of rope is at depends only upon the ratio of the downwards weight and tension forces to the horizontal drag force. If the order of magnitude of the downwards forces is much greater than the drag, then the angle must be very close to 0 (from the vertical) and if it’s the other way around, 90. For the scenario with the weight, you can tell the basic shape because of the edge case scenarios: the rope near the helicopter acts the same as the non-weighted case and the rope near the weight has downwards forces with an order of magnitude MUCH greater than the drag, so its angle must be near vertical. Because forces distribute smoothly in nature and there’s no other forces and thus another edge case in the middle of the rope, it must make a curve to fit what was shown in option D.

From a practical stand-point it depends on how fast you are going and the weight/volume ratio of the rope, since air-resistance is ∝ v²; so while moving slowly it will seem linear since the error from linear will be small. You can see in your "linear" video that it is not linear at the tail end of the rope - it drops faster like D. A shorter rope with a weight on it will emulate a long rope. It is never truly linear. Since rope is "dense" (in context) the weight pulls it down more than the resistance pulls it back so the answer is D. The parachute example shows what happens if the weight is low and air-resistance is high; then it becomes C. It will always be a parabola since gravity is always down and the relationship between speed and air-resistance is squared. If you took the helicopter straight up and didn't move at all then the rope would hang straight down. This is a degenerate test-case. Flying too slowly is also degenerate and causes the x² coefficient to be nearly zero.

That's not a cable in the conventional sense, try using a 1/2" twisted steel cable and you'll get "C". It's all about relative density and relative drag. Remember that as diameter is halved, relative drag is squared. Einstein gave man the gift of relativity, but man was too stupid to comprehend it. . . . U.S. Physics Olympiad team? however adding a helicopter with down force to the equation makes you wrong on 2 predictions.
you dismiss downforce as insignificant, yet the exam question does not state the downforce is insignificant, and the exam question uses a helicopter and not a fixed wing aircraft.
so 2 of your results and conclusions are WRONG
the shape of the rope would depend on the mass of the rope ( which is not stated, but can be assumed to be NOT zero or infinity )
the downforce would follow an inverse square rule proportional to distance from the source of the downforce
affecting the rope more at the top than the bottom.
so the correct answers are actually C, E, C
you are correct in your 3rd answer with C, but have not got there by fully investigating the mechanics of the question.
the exam question only asks for an answer to the first scenario ,( no weight on the end ) and clearly states that "air friction on the cable is NOT negligible )
In the question, the air is travelling BOTH Horizontally and vertically. ( the horizontal force is constant, the vertical follows inverse square law.
so your exam answer B is WRONG, in the actual exam though, I am almost certain that your INCORRECT answer of C would have been awarded as the CORRECT answer.
and clever students that actually got the answer CORRECT, would have been WRONGLY penalised .

To ad to the conversation on the interaction of the helicopter rotor wash - A helicopter in forward flight quickly passes through a phenomena called "effective translational lift" at ~20 to 40 knots indicated airspeed.  This phenomena is when the blades starts flapping (advancing side blade moves up, retreating blade moves down with each rotation) to compensate for different relative velocity around the rotor path plane.  The rotor wash directly beneath the helicopter is then negligible as it is increasingly "left behind"  the aircraft and the rotor increasingly processes fresh (an accelerated) air.  The pilot typically reduces the collective rotor pitch to compensate for this increased performance.  You can see this when a helicopter flies over water in close proximity at various speeds.  This phenomena greatly increases helicopter rotor lift (efficiency at converting engine kw to lift), so the helicopter pilot typically wants to get into the translational lift environment to save fuel and reduce engine power demand as quickly as possible.  The helicopter is also less vulnerable to engine failure in translational flight mode - if the engine failed it is easier to safely auto rotate to the ground with the energy and increased lift of forward flight added to the stored energy of the rotor rotating mass.  Their is something in the manual called the "death curve" typically.  It is graph of height versus airspeed.  On one side, and as you get further from the curve, the helicopter is easy to safely autorotate to the ground.  On the other side, it is unlikely you have sufficient combination of altitude, airspeed and rotor rpm to land safely if the engine catastrophically fails (instantaneous loss of engine power).

Alright, I have to comment here that this is very much a physics rather than reality question (I guess to be expected because it's a physics question).

The reality answer is E due to oscillation caused from air that is not uniform throughout the atmosphere. This will cause the rope to wag just as observed in the real demonstration forming the E shape.

The faster that helicopter goes (without a stabilizing weight at the end of the rope) the worse that oscillation will be depending on air densities and atmospheric movement along the length of the rope. The weight to length of rope also plays a role here.

This is the key reason why flying at speed in a helicopter with no weight on the end of the rope can be dangerous as any dense air pocket or moving air in the atmosphere could cause the rope to oscillate into the roters if there is not enough length/weight on the rope.

The question specifically says a helicopter is in play and drag is not negligible meaning that we must assume a dynamic non-uniform atmospheric composition that rope will be dragging though which will invariably cause the rope to oscillate (forming the E shape).

If the cable is short or the helicopter has massive backwash, the cable will hang straight down.

If the cable long it will hang at a straight angle.

If the cable is just long enough to interact with the backwash for half its length, it will curve increasingly more backwards.

This video proves that this specific rope is almost straight, but doesn't prove that it's 100% straight. If you're looking at this from a theoretical standpoint rather than a practical one, the rope would curve due to the downward force caused by wind of the helicopter blades since that force would be stronger the higher you get. Sure, it can be almost negligible compared to other forces present if the helicopter is moving fast, but if the helicopter is moving extremely slowly and the rope is very light (and short as well), I suspect it would have quite an impact. This would be very hard to test though because the lighter the rope, the more chaotically it'll move in a practical scenario.

The shape of the line can be predicted with calculus. A segment of length dl, hanging at an angle theta, with a mass dm and a force due to air resistance, dF where dF= Rdy, where R is a constant ( the force due to air resistance is a function of the projected area of dl on the y axis, with all the other constants fudged into R ). If we let p=linear density of the rope, then dm=pdl. Do the algebra and reduce down to dy and dx. Integrate it with initial condition of x=0, y=0 at the point of attachment, and voila, it is a straight line function.

Your explanation is a bit over complicated. Generally the rope will take a shape to minimize potential energy. So if the direction of the Force vector (weight + resistance) is constant then each part of the rope wants be as far away in that direction as possible, thus you get a straight line. If we have a weight at the end the end will want to be lower, thus you get your inverted j shape.

Back almost a century ago, my grandfather was in aviation. He was one of the first airplane pilots in Europe. He also was a good mathematician. The first flight computers owe some of their design to him. Those flight computers were cylindrical and rotated around a vertical axis mounted on top of the fuselage's right side. They had a little crank for that purpose.
My grandfather also published some articles on mathematics applied to aviation. One of the problems he analysed was how to determine when the mooring rope of a dirigible would slip over and when it would coil around a telegraph cable if both touched as the aircraft moved. It was a problem that affected safety and also wealth and communication: telegraph cables could snap, or the aircraft be stopped in flight!

I don't want to enter into personal stuff, but the test that Veritasium made is not a representation of the test itself, a cable is not a big rope, neither the flight of the helicopter is, you can enter into many details if you want, but pivoting forwards is not the same as just thrusting forwards, the way that the cable/rope is attached to the aircraft is centered to the mass, compared to the off axis test photo, and an important factor that is also neglected is that whether the aircraft started into a constant speed or is on a continued path with a constant speed. I appreciate your excellent effort. However, I think the weight of rope is higher to consider the actual shape of rope here.
Consider an air molecule closer to helicopter rotter blades. It’ll have high vertical velocity comparing to an air molecule away near end of rope which is far from rotter blades even though the relative horizontal velocity is equal at all the points.
So the resulting momental change rate direction is more horizontal at end of rope far from helicopter compared to the proximal part. So it should exert a greater force at end of rope horizontally.
Here the deflection should be so small to measure it visually. If you tried the experiment with an object with more surface area for air molecules to interact, I hope we can get more precise results. So still in my point of view it should be answer ‘c’ if we actually considering the deflection.

I believe that your explanation as to why it  has the various shapes it does is missing an element.  Each element of rope has 4 forces on it, not 3.  Drag, Weight Upward Tension, and Downward Tension.  If you were cut the rope at a point and put a person at that point holding the cut ends in each hand they would have to produce the 2 tension forces at that point.  So while your empirical evidence seems quite clear cut, your explanation is missing this other force and so is not complete.  I will admit that my original guess was C, and that was because I included this downward tension, but obviously came to the wrong conclusion by trying to do it in my head by intuition. For the exam problem as stated, B might be the observed/empirical answer, but C still is the correct analytical answer. The increase in air density at lower altitude creates increasing horizontal drag as you go lower on the rope providing an increasing horizontal force vector and the C shape. If the rope was longer (eg: 1,000') the result would be easily observable. But even without a longer rope, there is still slightly more air resistance lower on the rope creating shape C even if it is visually undetectable.

The imbalance in horizontal (drag) and vertical (gravity) force vectors is the same reason the answer is visually observable as C with the parachute and D with the weight. Just because the impact is smaller due to decreased air density at altitude doesn't mean it should be ignored.

Why state in the problem that "air friction on the cable is NOT negligible" if complete analysis of that friction (including air density changes with altitude) wasn't part of the problem to be solved?

I would be pissed if I was told my C answer was incorrect on that exam just because I didn't ignore a factor that I wasn't instructed to ignore that had notable impact on another factor I was specifically told to consider!

(Technically, there is an increase in the gravitational vector at lower altitudes as well, but it's change is negligible in comparison to the change in air density.)

It seemed to me that a moving helicopter should affect some portion of the air around itself, dragging it forward, thus decreasing the relative velocity of the air, and in turn, the magnitude of drag force in the top part of the rope – making the situation a little bit closer to the parachute test (I mean, the aspect that air resistance force above is less than below).
But it looks like this effect is some order of magnitude smaller than the forces actually affecting the situation (if present whatsoever) :(

This was an extremely easy question. It’s a scale, if the rope is all one weight then it’s proportional displaced. Aka a diagonal line. I reached the B conclusion working in reverse: every section of rope nearer to the helicopter has to support itself, plus all the farther sections. The farther sections will have less weight to support, but air resistance will have greater torque because they are a longer distance away to the fulcrum. The rope will remain straight because all the torque must be balanced by all the gravity.

The problem with this comes from physics vs real world. In physics the rope should behave one way once you have all the various information. But in real world application you have other factors at play, factors that will make replication of the question very difficult.

So in the question, everybody would assume that the rope is attached directly under the helicopter, in the middle. In real life you didn't do this, for safety reasons. So your conclusion that "b" is correct is flawed. Also, depending on altitude, various wind anomalies (airflow will be all over the place and different speeds) which would also vary depending on where on the planet you do the test. You also don't take into account that a helicopter points down when moving forward, something not shown on the question, so when you try and replicate it in the real world you ended up flying slowly but also on a diagonal.

In truth, it's a question that can't actual be answered. In a completely controlled environment the answer would be "b". But you're not even close to a controlled environment, you've invalidated the test just by the placement of the rope. And you might notice that you can see the end of the rope curving forwards every now and then, it shouldn't do that according to your explanation (which I do agree with).

My mid-video prediction for the weight at the end of the rope:
The middle of the rope will be bowed toward the downwind side, while the end is pulled semi-taut by the weight. Basically, the rope 'wants' to dangle at a greater angle to the rear than does the weight, since the weight itself has a much smaller ratio of drag force to weight force.
This solution can also be arrived at by considering an extreme example of an infinitely massive weight with very little wind drag that effectively behaves as a rigid support directly beneath the attachment point of the rope on the helicopter, and that translates along at the same speed as the helicopter.
Basically, you have a rope being held semi-taut between two fixed points in space and then a wind blows across the rope, giving it a bowed shape.

See. The problem with this question and your answer, is that the helicopter NEVER was at a constant speed. It was always accelerating.

If you have ANY analog force applied to something, you will never have a static acceleration between two points using a flexible tether. The tether will retract and stretch constantly. This removes and adds stress to the force required to pull the tethered object and the tether itself.

Sadly, this entire video is incorrect. The only correct option has to Have two waves, as seen in answer E.

The obvious issue with illustrating this is that the shape will flip.

I think your free-body diagram is missing the tension force in the opposite direction of the rope. Also, an interesting extension of this is for fluids where the resistance is much higher, e.g. towing fishing line through water. In that case, the amount of drag per unit of mass can change as the orientation of the cable changes, and you can even generate lift, which is why you need a weight on a downrigger line, or else it will basically run along the surface. Sincerely, Sci'06 grad.

The force acting on the rope from the air side should be perpendicular to the rope (not horizontal like the air flow). When air is blown onto the surface, the normal component of the impulse is transmitted, but the tangential component is not transmitted if the surface is smooth. The analogy is simple: the pressure of light. The force of light pressure is perpendicular to the mirror, although the light can fall as desired. The correct parallelogram of forces must be an inclined rectangle with a vertical diagonal (gravity) and inclined force of flow and reaction force.
It is very simple)

5:23 I dont think Fa will increase as we move up the rope. I think the answer depends on the velocity of the helicopter and the weight of the rope. It can either be B or C. After reaching a threshold velocity the rope becomes straight and the answer is B. But, before that velocity the answer is C. As we go up the rope, the weight of the rope increases, thereby increasing the Fg. But, Fa remains the same. In the video, velocity was quite high so the Fa component was significantly higher than Fg, no matter where we choose the point on the rope to draw the Free Body Diagram. That's why the rope was straight.

Nice video. My original prediction was C, and here's why I picked that. As the copter moves through the air, it creates a bow wave of air such that the rope near the copter is experiencing less air resistance than the rope farther from the copter. Similar to what race cars experience when drafting. Hence, the rope farther away will curve as in C. My guess is that the copter in the video wasn't going fast enough to create a large enough bow wave.

I paused the video to think about the multiple choice question at the beginning.  I was pretty sure that "the catch" has to do with the effect of the air coming down from the rotor. I assumed this effect should decrease the further down we are below the helicopter. However, none of the answers seem to agree with this. Not even E (it twists the wrong way).
So I went on watching and learnt, to my surprise, that this effect is nearly negligible. This surprised me because the force propelling this airflow should support the full weight of the copter (the light air must move down very fast).
The expert explained that: "the rotor wash doesn't extend below down that far; it dissipates pretty quickly". I assume he is right -- but I want to point out that I believe that this cannot be strictly deduced by the observation of the experiment here:
Suppose that the rotor airflow effect does dissipate slowly and the change is hardly noticeable for the first 15m or so. What happens then?
I think that this can be viewed as if the net air flow (while the copter is moving) is no longer horizontal but at an angle now. The air force on the cable now has a downward vertical component.
The ratio between the vertical and the horizontal components of the total net force will now change, but this ratio will still be uniform throughout the cable!
So I guess we should still observe a straight line (choice B), only steeper.

To strictly verify that the answer is indeed B (and does not turn into C) - this should be tested with a much longer rope.

I know you’ll never see this comment because it’s 10k deep at this point, but I thought of a riddle that I’d really like answered maybe other commenters can help me:

Imagine you’re stuck at the top of an impossibly broad plateau, and you want to lower yourself over the ledge with a rope to escape. The problem is that there is nothing on the plateau to tie a rope to. It may as well be the bonneville salt flats. So my question is this: with a long enough rope, would it be possible to simply lay the rope down in a straight line away from the cliff edge in such a way that only the weight of the rope is enough to support you as you descend?

Rephrased slightly; if you dangle let’s say 1% of the total rope over the edge and the other 99% of the rope is just sprawled across the plateau, will friction alone be enough to stop you from falling as you climb down that 1%?

Are you accounting for the downwash from the rotors of the helicopter? I would like to bring some more aerodynamics into the picture. Heres my theory: The downwash creates a curtain of downward airflow which is zero velocity at the center of the rotor, and peak velocity at the edges of the rotor. When the helicopter now moves forward at the constant velocity, this downwash from the rotors combined with the airspeed, makes the resultant "curtain" go a fixed angle backwards? and the hence causes a linear application of drag along the rope. Theres also the airflow around and under the nose of the aircraft which should cause non-linear drag at the top of the rope (which probably doesnt happen if you account for the downdraft from the rotors.) If you notice the bottom end of the rope, its wagging in air and never stable since its likekly outside this curtain of downdraft and in turbulent airflow.

Id be interested in seeing a CFD model including the chopper, and its rotors producing downwash, and including the outwash effects from the nose of the helicopter, and how they interact with the downwash. Yay, I got it right! And my logic was the same too. I imagined the rope as split into lots of small slices. The weight+resistance and tension would obviously have to be balanced for each 'slice' of rope, of it would stretch. And if you look at a single slice anywhere on the rope, the forces acting on it, while varying in overall magnitude, look the same.

The forces on the first slice that make it sit at a certain angle are the same as the forces on the last slice. It's just that the slice is displaced by the slices above. Therefore the angle is constant.

Plot twist: The only right answer is A actually .

The question states “as the helicopter flies through the air to the right”, and as we clearly view the helicopter from the right in the diagram, that means the helicopter would be moving towards our viewpoint and the rope would form a diagonal line away from our viewpoint.

Henceforth we would see a straight line down as in answer (A), because we would be looking in line with the plane in which the rope translates.

I wonder if answer (A) would’ve given zero points because that ‘wasn’t how the question was meant’, but without clarifying the direction specifically (like to the right from our viewpoint, or to the right on this paper), one should assume basic rules of logic, as in: a helicopter flies to the right (from the pilot’s viewpoint) and a doctor should surgically remove the left arm not from when he views the sedated patient facing him, but from the patients anatomy.

I used to get pretty frustrated when I would find quiz errors like this at school. It happened very often.

Pick any point on the rope. Analyze forces on the section of the rope below that point. Weight pulls down and is proportional to the length of the section. Air resistance is horizontal and is also proportional to the length of the section.

So regardless of which point you choose and which length you analyze, the vertical and horizontal forces are proportional... which means the total force forms a constant angle. And the rope is diagonal.

This is why analyzing forces will always win over intuition. Yay Newton.

Edit: I wrote the above after pausing at 4:08. Didn't realize he was going to make the same explanation right after.

There is a variable here that is not tested. From experience having artillery pieces sling loaded and moved in the army, I would say that the presumption that the rotor wash does not extend is dependent on the weight and size of the aircraft. Having to carry and artillery piece amount of weight requires ALOT of downward thrust. Additionally, the shape of the aircraft effects how protected the rope is from that downward thrust. For example, a Chinook with a double rotor makes a different shape in the line than a Blackhawk. In your example you have a relatively small commercial aircraft with 3 passengers under close to ideal conditions. Increase the size and weight of the aircraft, and the results at least with regards to the effect of downward thrust on the rope will vary greatly.

yeah, people don't grasp rotor wash much, I think part of that is people have a mindset that the helicopter is lifing up because it is pushing alot of air down; when what is really happening is the rotors are spinning wings, and the helicopter is lifing because it's being pushed up by the air below the rotor into the low pressure area created by the "wing" (rotor) created by the wings movement through the air.

So my prediction before he even got to the explanation was B. Why is it B, with my limited understanding of physics and my fairly decent understanding of aeronautics? The force acting upon the rope as it moves is mostly uniform across the surface of the rope, there is the downward force of the rotor wash and the forward (in this case diagonal) force of the helicopter, which uniformly pushes the rope backwards along its length. Of course the latter is called air resistance, or more simply, drag. Depending on the length and speed of the rotor blades, the distance at which rotor wash would dissipate varies. The rope being 50 feet long, the end of the rope is no longer affected by the rotor wash in any significant way. Assuming the weight of the rope is uniform across the length, the amount of drag has to be uniform across it's surface. This causes the rope to drag behind the helicopter in a straight diagonal line, versus having any sort of curve. This effect changes when you add weight, this is due to the amount drag changes (particularly over the weight itself) and the tension on the line.

I actually rig externally slung loads , the flag was never going to cause an issue because it wasn't a solid surface that would present significant surface area to the direction of travel to cause an issue. The small parachute can actually be used to stabilise loads in flight. The biggest issue is having a load that is light with a large surface area which will cause the load to become unstable or "float" dependant on KIAS. And just for fun, a square/cuboidal load will spin as all surface areas are equal and won't settle in one direction which will require a hook and swivel so the sling doesn't coil up bringing the load closer to the helo, a rectangular load will fly presenting the short and long side to the wind as it is the largest surface area

Answering this question isn't trivial at all. After all it is aerodynamics. The rope you used is rigid and heavy. The situation would definitely change with a less rigid and lighter (thinner) rope. Here are some of the effects that would strongly affect a thin rope. 1.) The air pushed down by the rotor of the helicopter, 2.) the difference in windspeed near the body of the helicopter and at the end, 3.) turbulences created by the helicopter (which strongly depend on traveling speed) 4.) depending on the material of the rope and the speed the rope would get thinner due the tension (with enough length the rope would rip). That is why experiments in physics are so important. Simulations of reality can be really difficult.

Now: If you're interested in exploring a really crazy concept actually used by missionary fixed-wing pilots to descend and retrieve items to fields too small for landing, consider reading about how they would tightly circle the field while paying out rope to which they'd attached an item, often a bucket or bag at the end of the rope. The rope followed a spiral shape, but at some point the end would settle on a point and just be lowered vertically to the ground, where an attendant would retrieve and replace the contents, usually mail, but sometimes much-needed medicine or other supplies.

This is the way prejudice and ignorance are perpetrated through academic institutions. Come up with absurd question. Don't give context. Then make it an important test question that will determine your career and how you can make money or not.

If you are from the same culture, and "smart", You'll make the same assumptions about the context as the culture of the one who wrote the question. If you aren't (and you've seen a helicopter in real life do it differently) then you are "dumb" and you can't prove us wrong because our idealized model (that doesn't resemble the real world, unless you assume the specific pilot etc etc) says that our answer is "objectively" true.

Better science would be to define the context and confess the many unknowns and uncertainties. But that doesn't make a good multiple choice question and won't weed out the non-white candidates to the SAT.

Assuming the top of the rope can rotate freely in any direction (or at least about the axis that is perpendicular to the direction of travel). As soon as you constrain the top of the rope to any  orientation other than it's equilibrium angle (if it was unconstrained), you will get answer (C) due to the bending stiffness. In the video if they had flown exactly to the pilot's right it would have been a different result because the rope would not be able to rotate freely to the left side of the helicopter. Admittedly, the bending stiffness of the rope is a major factor, so this effect would be more pronounced on deplaning ropes with metal cores.

This reminds me of a rescue technique that was experimented with, maybe 1st or 2nd WW, using a rope suspended beneath a fixed wing aircraft. With a sufficiently long rope and with the aircraft flying in a tight circle, the end of the rope would dangle nearly motionless on or near the ground. A person could then attach to the rope, the aircraft could widen out it's turn and the person would be lifted from the ground and flown off to a another location. Placing the person back on the ground would then be a reversal of the process. I don't know if it was ever adopted in anger, so to speak, because of the risks involved.

Before I watch. I answered the survey before C, but now Im thinking that its B. I tried to think through a model of segments of the cable. The very end has gravity and drag (down and back) so the balancing force of tension from the cable must have an up and forward vector. As you move up the cable, each segment has the same drag and weight plus the drag and weight of each other segment. All segments being uniform, these summed forces will have the same net direction.

Edit: at 6:24 so I'll disregard drag on the kettle bell for a second and go through the same process. The end segment now has the weight of the kettle bell plus the weight of itself and its drag. This direction is more downward than a free hanging rope segment. So the tension will need to be more upward. As you move up the rope, you are adding additional force vectors with slightly less downward component proportionally. I predict the rope will take the shape of D.

Edit after watching: so my original flaw when I answered the survey was... well I was lazy... but also I considered the infinitesimal end of the rope to have drag and no weight. But of course if it has no mass it has no cross sectional area either so that was stupid.

Anyway, thanks, Derek!

Summary:

Case 1 (no weight): Constant air resistance throughout the rope so it will form a straight line (option B)

Case 2 (with weight at the end): Air resistance at the middle is more that it is at the bottom hence a C shape (option D)

Case 3 (with a parachute at the end): Air resistance at the bottom is more that it is at the middle hence a J shape (option C)

That's almost exactly how I solved it, except I worked the opposite direction.

First I really cemented the idea that all the forces acting on the rope would be continous and cumulative. At the top of the rope the dominant acting force would be gravity as its supporting the rest of the rope. As you work your way down the rope the pull of gravity would decrease correspondingly. Then I worked from the bottom up reasoning out the force applied by wind resistance well also gravity would be negligible. Then working your way up the force applied by the cumulative amount surface area would decrease in lock step with gravity.

Least that's the easiest way I can think to describe my reasoning, I visualize two graphs and concluded they'd have to be perfectly linear bar external interference.

Awesome video, but I think there are four right answers depending solely on the the force of gravity (Fg) and the drag (Fa) on the cable:

(A) when Fa/Fg approaches zero. Heavy cable with no drag, like a thin cable made of depleted uranium. Or, if you prefer Answer B with 0 degree angle between the helicopter and the cable. As long as Fa/Fg is zero, the helicopter's speed doesn't matter.


(B) when Fa/Fg is less than 1 like the initial case in the video.

(C) when Fa/Fg is greater than 1 like a lighter weight rope than the one used in the video or the same rope at higher speed. This was hinted at with the parachute experiment. The cable will begin to curve upward at the point along the cable where Fa/Fg becomes greater than one. Above that point Fa/Fg = 1, below that point Fa/Fg increases as the weight of the remaining cable (Fg) decreases and Fa remains constant.

(F) Helicopter crash when Fa/Fg approaches infinity and cable is sucked into main or tail rotor. Cable is all drag and no weight, like silk or muppet fur.

Well, I picked the option C. I tried to explain myself as following. Please do read the full explanation:
As altitude increases the density of air decreases (due to earth's gravity) so does the frictional force on the rope. Hence as you go up along the rope, with the height increasing there should be an increase in the radius of curvature of the rope. Thus option c should be correct as it shows the according figure.
But as an explanation to your experimental results, I can say
1. The rope was not long enough to demonstrate that curl.
2. The height of your helicopter was too low. The rate of change in air density with respect to altitude increases as altitude increases. So when the helicopter is near the earth the rope experiences negligible amount of change in air density.

I used to often ask motorcycle riders and even my professors at engineering school this question.

If you are riding a motor cycle down a perfectly flat and straight road at 50 MPH and slightly pull with your right hand and push with your left hand, which way will the motorcycle turn?

It will go left which is counter intuitive. I found many long term motorcycle riders, who do this everyday, didn't even realize they were doing it. Yes, there is a transition point where this happens. At 2 MPH you will go right but at some speed, this will flip to the left due to the gyro effect. At precisely what speed is dependent on the motorcycle and rider.

"Rotor wash does not extend below the helicopter all that far" is somewhere between untrue and a misunderstanding of "not that far". We were supposed to have a chinook fly into town for a veteran's day event and they had to call it off because the buildings around the landing area (a local grocery store parking lot that held ~60 cars) would have their roofs ripped off by the downwash during landing. That would mean it has to be affecting things hundreds of feet away. Also you see the ripples in the sand in footage where soldiers are repelling from a helicopter (so there's wind blowing down beyond the length of their ropes).

Also if you think about things by extrapolating to the extremes and then working their way back towards the normal: an infinitely light rope would be far more affected by air currents while an infinitely heavy rope would not be affected by air currents. I would think it stands to reason that there's some point of rope weight/density where the answer shifts from B to C, that point would be where rotor downwash has significant impact over the trailing direction of the rope. I feel like a streamer would look more like C while a chain would look more like B.

The real-life example is great. However I don't think your explanation is very good. My attempt: There are actually four forces acting on each segment of the rope: drag and weight, which are constant for each segment, as well as two tensions: tension pulling the segment up coming from the segment above, and tension pulling down from below coming from the weight of the rope. This DIFFERENCE in tensions is the force that is being balanced by weight and drag. The difference in tensions turns out to be constant along the length of the rope. Think about the zero-wind case -> there is a constant force pulling down on each segment of the rope. The tension pulling the rope up is equal to the weight of the rope below the top of the segment, and the tension pulling it down is equal to the weight of the rope below the bottom of the segment (which is shorter, and thus less). So the net tension on the segment is exactly equal, but opposite to the weight of the segment, because this is the difference in weights. The case with a constant air velocity is equivalent (drag plus gravity are always the same magnitude, and directed in the same direction, just like gravity in the case of no wind), so we get the same solution - a straight line - just rotated by the angle of the vector which is the sum of the gravity and drag vectors.

To me and others who I watched the video with, it looks as if you are talking only about tension pulling up - I think it would help if you explicitly broke out the tension into the pair of forces, and showed that it was constant along the length of the rope, and that the zero wind case is equivalent to the constant air velocity case - a little diagram similar to the ones you already had would be all that's needed.

These explanations seem a bit off. 1) Every section of rope is supporting all the rope beneath it, so the direction of the force of the weight is not just straight down and increases as the portion being looked at approches the helicopter. 2) Each segment of rope experiences its own drag plus all of the drag it is negarting from all portions of rope beneath it.

I see that these factors were taken into account by the animations sometimes in this video but not always. In the first case, weight and drag should be increasing in equal proportion as you ascent the rope.

This should be true for all cases. The reason the rope takes a particular shape is due to the boundary conditions of the rope.

In example 2, you show weight remaining constant along the length of the rope. Each section should feel the drag and weight of all sections beneath it, meaning the force it experiences is not constant.

I suppose this is kind of less of a physics question, and more of an engineering question: this problem is fairly easy to model by combining fluid mechanics and statics (material mechanics if you want to go the extra mile and account for the ropes small but non-zero bending stiffness)

The video you took was viewing from the front of the aircraft travel which I feel was distorting the result of the rope, it would have taken the E shape if it was long enough, for the following reasons. A the length of the rope eventually over comes the air resistance, B the moving parcel of air is affecting the angle of the rope causing it to lean back further than if the air was still i.e. if the air is moving you need to factor this into the equation. That's an interesting video, but I think the question is badly worded because it requires the student to make the same assumptions about the cable and the forward speed of the helicopter that the examiner has made. When the helicopter is hovering the rotor wash and its effect on the cable is far from negligible. The pilot says this at 1:12 and we see it at 1:58. As forward speed increases the helicopter leaves its rotor wash behind, and so the cable moves through unaffected air. There is also the weight of the perfectly flexible cable. The heavy battle rope is chosen for safety - specifically so that it would be less affected by rotor wash. A lighter cable would be more likely to show the effect of the rotor wash at low forward speeds, and look more like C - but it would also be more likely to whip around dangerously.
Better wording for the exam question would have been: "Air friction on the cable is not negligible, but the effect of rotor wash is."
As it is, I think the answer is "mostly B - but some cases C - it depends."

Wow, next day and there are nearly 8000 comments. Here's my engineering background take on this. Each unit length of rope (millimetre, inch, foot, yard, metre or whatever) has a drag force on it due to the horizontal movement through the atmosphere. It also has a force due to gravity acting on its mass. The resultant vector force on each of these unit lengths will be the same so the rope should hang in a straight line with the angle being determined by the drag force and gravitational force. The only issue is how long the transition from stationary to horizontal movement at a steady state takes for everything to settle down and does the downwash from the rotor disk have an effect. Well the rotor wash will have a limited range and the dampening effect of the rope moving in a viscous fluid (air) will quickly result in a steady state.

I have now watched the video and it matches what I thought. My engineering degree and 40+years of engineering practice wasn't wasted then.

Right answer, even after watching the video, sould be C, although, the amount of curvature depends on the weight and wingspan (if you will) of the aircraft. This from the very beginning seemed like the non-intuitive answer was C therefore it’s C, but because the obvious 5-year-old answer is B, and that’s where you start before you consider the interplay that makes C or E right teaser answers; Such that the harder you consider B the less you should consider C over D as an alternative answer, E and then D seem like the best answers after B. Aka if it’s not the most obvious at B it may be a ‘widget’ at E. This is why multi-choice over essay exams are not nearly as empirical. This is why I passed chem2 in college and my study partner on the departmental exam failed. Multi-choice testing is a scam to proving knowledge. The professor saying option B is harder than option D to imagine is interesting because it doesn’t seem that scenario B is hard to imagine it seems like the ‘keep it simple stupid’ answer/kiss principle to describing how the rope should behave. You get those easy answers right and you start to get the rest of the test, its works on the LSAT and Bar exams too, the more multi-choice they are the less empirical.

Weeeell, not going to diss this video, but there is a pretty good point to argue for nearly ALL answers just from watching this video if you take exactly one or two shots as proof for either answer, at least in the close up details.
While the answer given in the video seems to be the most consistent for most of the time for most of the rope, nearly all shapes shown as possible in the exam did show up in tiny variations at the end of the rope at some point during the video. So while in general the answer given is mostly correct for the large whole of the setup I would like to see more in depth studies regarding the small details along the extreme limits of the setup. Before watching this, I just need to comment, it couldn't be A, unless the rope is weighted at the bottom or unless the helicopter is moving upward or not in motion. As for the answer, C sort of makes sense because you'd move the top of the helicopter first and the bottom of the rope would drag behind,  but that would end up looking like B after a moment of motion (it would look like C and then like B when the motion continues in that direction). D would only occur if there is a strong headwind and the helicopter is flying into it and possibly descending slightly (accounting for that curvature). E is very possible. So i'd actually guess E, the bottom of the rope stays in place where the top is moved by the helicopter initially, but then it looks like B, because the question says "constant speed" which would imply the rope should be a straight line?

So I thought it was B, but more for a reason not mentioned:  inertia. I feel like it would be B even without air resistance, due to inertia. Sure, air resistance is a factor, and makes the diagonal angle greater, but I still think it would be somewhat diagonal without it. It takes time for information to fall down the rope to the end, I believe based on its natural frequency (like sending waves down a rope, cracking a whip, etc.). Or similar to how the bottom of a hanging slinky did not know the top is dropped until it reaches the end to fall together. So I think even if the rope is hanging on a constant speed monorail in a vacuum (or moon), I think you'll still have a diagonal, albeit steeper angle without air resistance.

I'm not 100% convinced by this; when the question was first posed, I imagined the rope was FIXED to the bottom of the helicopter, which would mean that the very top portion of the rope would have a vertical vector of tension. The way you have it dangling out of the cabin leaves the top free to rotate, so it can be pulled straight in the overall direction of tension, instead of displaying a curve transitioning from a fixed end to the free flying end. Given the safety concerns in this experiment, I can see why you went with this approach, however if other people thought like I did, then I think it clearly misrepresents what is being asked. I am open to being wrong of course, but I would really like to see a vertically fixed attachment point (vertical relative to the ground when travelling) to be thoroughly convinced. I expect to see a curve that is some function of air resistance, gravity, and the stiffness of the rope. A rope with zero stiffness would be no different to the results in your experiment of course, but as the stiffness increases, you would surely see a curve approaching the majoritively picked answer. I mean, don't rent a whole-ass helicopter again on my account, but I do wonder if other people are as unsatisfied with this test as I am. No disrespect of course, your videos are always interesting and entertaining. And the shape with the weighted end was actually surprising to me. omg you know what, I bet if you ran this experiment with the top fixed as I described above, AND a weight on the free end, You would get something like the S curve, again dependant on the stiffness of the rope. I guess the best way to describe my reasoning: If you did this with a pole of 100% stiffness, there would be no question, we could all agree it would point straight down (if it was a fixed attachment point and not free to rotate, as mentioned). Similarley, a rope of 0% stiffness would have an infinitely small bend radius and so any amount of evenly applied force would cause it to be angled from the attachment point but otherwise perfectly straight. Of course reality is nowhere near these ideals, but clearly there is some in-betweens that we CAN test, in order to better describe this problem. As for a practical way to test this, if you WERE to approach it again, my suggestion would be a tube that the rope can be passed through but it is a tight fit (or can be tightened), and that this tube has some kind of mounting bracket that give a consistent fixed angle of dangle, maybe it would even be worth this being a variable angle so you could test with the rope exiting the tube horizontally forwards and back. And also different stiffnesses of rope to test (same density and cross-sectional surface area preferably, I have no idea how realistic that would be to find though)

edit: just to be clear, when I said not convinced by, I meant not satisfied with. Clearly, the result is true for this test case, only the statement of the problem I feel was ambiguous such that it has not been thoroughly answered. I answered C like most people, based on the assumption that the rope was fixed. I thought it would be because all of the rope would have the same amount of wind resistance, but the lower down the rope you go, the less mass from the rope above it is a factor, so it would be more affected by the wind relative to it's cross-sectional area to the direction of travel (but also each section's area of resistance would be changed since the angle from one section would be inherited by the one below it). I was trying to balance the forces, but in a way that I think overcomplicates it. The way you showed the balancing of the forces was simpler, but it feels more like "this is the result we see, therefore the forces must be thus", rather than predictive? Again no disrespect, I struggle to put my mind thoughts into words so I ramble and can lose my point, but I hope this is clear enough. I just want to see the results for different stiffnesses of rope, and to have this done with a controlled point of attachment, so we can see how the shape of the curve changes

Actually no, his observation is incorrect. Look again at this test, the end of the rope is waving back and forth. So, the end of the rope is in fact curving as shown in diagram C, but then as it curves up the end section moves out of the air flow and then drops. At one point the momentum allows it to drop in the opposite direction, until the air pressure catches it again and pushes it back up. You can clearly see the lower half of the rope is moving around far more than the upper half.
So B is only the correct answer if you catch and freeze a particular moment of the experiment. At other moments it looks like C and even a bit of D. The weight on the rope is not constant over its entire length, the lower half has much less weight/tension on it and is therefore affected to a greater degree by air pressure. How is this not obvious? Is this one of those teaching techniques?

An easy way to figure out questions like this is often to consider extreme cases. Just thinking about it intuitively, if we made the bottom part of the rope weightless, or equivalently, if a very large weightless balloon was attached at the bottom of the rope - it's relatively straightforward to see we'd get the C shape - either via intuition or some very basic back-of-the-envelope calculations. On the other hand, if we had a very heavy weight, it's similarly straightforward to see we'd get the D shape. Plotting a few of the points that are equal distant from these C and D lines gives us the answer when nothing is affixed to the end  - a straight line.

Here is an explanation:

It will be “A” if there is no air resistance but there is Gravity.
“B” If there are both Air resistance and Gravity it is diagonal because of the moment arm so as we see the further we go towards tip the more it is lagging (behind compared to the helicopter position).
“C” If the rope gets thinner and thinner as we move more towards the tip (both forces acting).
“D” If there is weight tied to the tip and rope is more flat/thick and helicopter is moving a lot faster (both forces acting)
“E” if rope is more thinner in the middle compared to the near tip and base, and if helicopter is moving faster and weight toed to the tip ( but that doesn’t really matter much and yes both forces acting here too).

I work with helicopters with ropes pretty frequently. So it's a straight line with no load. Curved down with a load. The rotor wash extends down pretty far, that's why a normal pilot can't hover below 1000 feet. But it's simply adding to the force due to gravity. And then your air resistance is from the front, air resistance is constant along the rope, force due to gravity is decreasing along the length. Thus it hangs straight. With a load that relationship is no longer linear and is expressed in the rope.

I disagree with the answer being "B" as a generalized statement for the first instance of having no weight attached. At risk of being wrong publicly, I believe the answer should be more accurate to "C", for any given length of rope. "B" seems to be the right answer, visually, but I believe that is only the case due to the relatively short length of the rope. Since air density is exponentially higher in the -z-direction, and each segment of rope is being pulled in the +x-direction with nearly the same velocity, it would imply that the force in the -x-direction would become exponentially higher as the rope reached the ground, giving it the same shape we saw in "C". As a sanity check, we should take this idea to its limits. A segment of rope moving in the +x-direction in exoatmosphere would have virtually no force in the -x-direction to due low air density, and would hang vertically downwards. A segment of rope moving in a thick atmosphere close to the ground moving at high speed would have a very large force in the -x-direction, and would hang more horizontally.

Nope, the scenario in the question doesn't mention velocity nor aircraft speed as a major factor. Based on the video, the helicopter wasn't traveling at a typical speed (90-120 knots more if tandem rotors) in forward operation. It was almost at a hover (come on, 60 knots is slow). The pilot brought up an interesting question about the rope coming into the tailrotor or into the main rotor. Neither would happen due to the weight of the rope (fast rope operation). If the rope weighed very little, it may wrap around the aircraft but we don't use little ropes, we use big fat ropes that can handle the weight of several combat equipped troops (fast rope). For sling load operations, the slingloads may oscillate during single hook operations (fore and aft). In this case the pilot just reduces speed to stop the oscillation. If the pilot in this test had reached typical operational speed (90 -120 knots), the rope would have looked like answer C, D, E, and pretty much all the answers. This is based on 17 years of flying single rotor and tandem rotor helicopters. In a tandem rotor system, we don't have a tail rotor to slow us down so our VNE (Velocity Never to Exceed) is well over 170 knots (or the official answer is "we don't have a VNE"). The CH-47 helicopter wants to go fast due to the tilt of the rotor system (9 degree front, 4 degrees aft) and the design of the platform (nose low). If this test were repeated at normal operating speeds, the rope would not be diagonal as shown in the video. What you had was a pilot who was being very cautious, not a tactical pilot. One of the reasons for the answer C being correct is due to forward velocity, plus the downward draft of the rotor system. The part of the rope that is closest to the helicopter (top of the rope) will move at the speed of the aircraft because it has no choice (attached to helicopter). The tail of the rope (bottom) will be aft of the top just like a flag in the wind (all over the place). Helicopters have a downward rotorwash that impacts (kinda cushions) upward lift (Effective Transnational Lift (ELT)). Yeah, I'm not supposed to say "cushion" because it's not a aerodynamic term but it fits this answer. Which leads us to the big point that wasn't taken into consideration: rotarywing aerodynamics in forward flight. The rope "hang" will change based on the speed of the helicopter (forward velocity), the speed (and size) of the overhead rotor system (downward draft), as well as the weight of the rope. If you put that rope on the main (center cargo) hook of a CH-47 and ask us to fly slow, that thing will flap like a wet dog. Ask us to accelerate to normal forward flight and it will bend to become answer A, B, C, D, E, F, all depending on airflow over the rope itself. Not physics, aerodynamics.
