@Veritasium I've been a radio engineer for 40 years and many years ago I thought of a question for which I still don't have an answer. It goes like this:
On the inverse square law for radiation
We know that radio signal strength decreases with distance according to an inverse square law so that if you double your distance from the source (a radio transmitter) the received field strength is decreased by four. This comes from the fact that you can consider the wave front as the surface of an expanding sphere and the surface area of a sphere (field strength) is proportional to the square of the radius (distance from the radio transmitter). This is true whether the transmitter's antenna is omni-directional (equal energy in all directions) or focused in one direction. If it's spreading AT ALL the energy will decrease according to the inverse square law.

Now consider a perfect laser where the energy is confined to a single narrow beam that doesn't diverge at all. In that case wouldn't the energy arriving at the far end be the same as it was when it left? It's not spreading out. If so here's the crunch. If the signal spreads to ANY degree it will follow the inverse square law but if it doesn't, it won't. So at what point as we approach "zero spread" does the inverse square law fail?

I'm just at the beginning of the video, and I'm going with B, the swept back straight line. My reasoning is that both the force of the air resistance, and the force of gravity are proportional to the length of any given stretch of cable in the same way. The increase in leverage with longer lengths is the same for both a torque applied by gravity and by air resistance, and the angle away from vertical for gravity and from horizontal for air resistance follows the same sinusoidal function. Because the forces scale in the same proportion to length, and because it is is perfectly flexible, it must be a straight line. It must be swept back to be in equilibrium because at dead vertical, gravity applies no torque, but wind force applies a positive torque. The angle of the sweep will be determined by the density and aerodynamic properties of the cable.

Here is why. Obviously it’s really cool to jump on a helicopter and show the physics in action, but in a test this is very different.

I believe the the rope alone acts as a lever as it is fixed to the helicopter. Therefore it has a moment at every point down the rope. If the air resistance is the exact same down the rope then as the distance increases so does the resultant moment; leading to proportional displacement down the rope.
If drawn on a graph it would create the exact shape of the rope at any given point.
It could be proved that tension in the rope is negligible if a spring was attached between the heli and the rope; the rope would still be a perfect straight line even if the tension was fluctuating.
I would like to see this done with a lighter rope.

The rotor wash does extend below the helicopter, and becomes more turbulent as it interacts with the airstream. What people forget though is the column of downwash behaves just like the rope; it falls behind the helicopter as it speeds up. Wait, the length of the rope was never determined, so we just assume it to be any length.  If it's an extremely long rope, reaching just above ground level, we would encounter maximum air pressure, and thus maximum air resistance at the bottom.  We also don't know the height of the helicopter, so we must assume it can be any possible height.  If we assume the helicopter is at a maximum reasonable height, say 25,000 get above sea level, air resistance would be non-negligibly lower than at sea level.  If that were the case, there should be a convex profile for the rope descended.

I think that both B and C are correct for the first case (no load or parachut atrached) depending on the density of the rope. If the density of the rope is relatively high, then the shape of the rope will be closer to C. Decreasing the density of the rope, the shape will tend toward linear shape (i.e. the B shape is a special case of the more general shape C).

the rotor wash would have effects only in case it produces a variable (along the rope) downward force along the rope. If it dissipates immediately it is a line (you explained that). Even if it never dissipates we can incorporate its effect rotating the apparent wind direction for the rope. It would be equivalent to an elicopter without rotor wash that also climbs. The shape of the rope is affected only by forces that change along the rope.

Actually, to be precise, the wind speed is not constant along the rope since near the helicopter the air moves with the helicopeter. However, this zone is in the order of cms (I guess) so the effect is completely negligible and hidden by the fact that the rope isn't perfectly flexible

Phd in mechE here, awesome video as usual. I wonder if there is a bit more to this story...your explanation statement that says "the ratio of air resistance to weight is the same at every point along the rope" (5:40) is perhaps contestible. I would propose the air drag/resistance, Fa, is constant along the length of the rope, but the weight, Fg, varies linearly along the length of the rope due to the concatenating tension phenomena as you explained. A constant summed with a quantity that varies linearly along a spatial dimension still results in a linear output function (straight rope), but the statement that the ratio between the two forces is equal along that spatial dimension is probably incorrect. In fact I would take it a step further and argue that the implied general statement that the ratio between these two forces needing to remain equal is required for output linearity is probably not necessary--even if the air resistance varied along the length of the rope, as long as it did so linearly, would still result in a linear output function (rope in a straight line) since a linear function summed with another linear function still results in a linear output, even if the slope of those two summed functions were not the same (which would also result in a ratio between these two forces that vary along the length of the rope). Happy to entertain dissenting opinions on this though :).

The introduced weight (and parachute) clearly introduce a nonlinear lumped parameter on the legnth of the rope, which explains the nonlinear output function. I'll eat my pride and admit this was not my initual intuition when you added the weight, but hey, nonlinear systems are non-intuitive :). You did an awesome job contextualizing this effect with the added mass and the parachute--honestly a lot of really great stuff here, but done in a very accessible way. Thank you also for not making me watch 10 minutes into the video for the correct answer (you're sticking to your long term promise of tantalizing video titles with informative content).

Before watching the result:
C; the drag force on each element of the rope is for the moment assumed to be equal. The shape will then be determined by the combination of the tension, equal throughout the rope, and the incremental weight of the rope below each segment. The weight below is greatest right at the helicopter and linearly decreases the further down the rope we look. Right near the end the weight below approaches 0. So the force pulling the rope down is highest at the helicopter and decreases as we go down the rope. That means the rope should be most vertical at the helicopter and increasingly bend away from the wind as we approach the bottom tip.

easy - of course its gonna make a curved shape like C:
dF'=0.5*rho*V^2dx
so then:
dM'=0.5*rho*V^2*x*dx -> M(x)=0.25*rho*(V^2)*(x^2) -> parabolic dependence on "x".

furthermore, it cant be a straight line because then the slope of the rope would be discontinuous at the helicopter (that can't happen). this is a classic cantilever problem lol

I still think that given the specifics of the problem, the best choice is C. The helicopter from the video may have a fairly small rotor wash, but the curve would be much more apparent with a larger rotor such as on a Black Hawk, or one with a smaller body like a Cobra gunship. In any case, the author specifically chose a helicopter for the problem statement. Not an airplane, not a train going over a long bridge, but a helicopter. In a problem where air resistance is explicitly stated to be non-negligible, the only appropriate answer is C. Answer B requires assuming horizontal air forces to be non-negligible, but rotor wash forces to be negligible. If that was the intent, they shouldn't have picked a helicopter as the object towing the rope.

This is one of those "F*** you" questions that trips up people who actually think about them. If you've never seen it before, getting it right entirely depends on whether or not you know that rotor wash doesn't extend below the helicopter. The question even sets you up to think about rotor wash by specifying that air drag is not negligible. And the sad thing is it could be a really good question - if it wasn't multiple choice. Multiple choice gives you no opportunities to elaborate, where a smart student might consider both scenarios regarding rotor wash and express that in a text-based answer. This is assuming the test didn't provide space for clarifications of course, if it did I have no gripes with it.

Thank you for the demo though, the video was certainly interesting!

I think a lot of people picked C because they sort of imagine the end lagging behind as the helicopter starts moving, because that's how you would probably start to imagine the scenario: the helicopter isn't moving, and the rope is hanging downwards, and then it starts moving, bringing the portion of the rope closest to itself along with it first. But the question states that the helicopter isn't just getting started - it's asking what the rope shape stabilizes towards as the helicopter moves at a constant speed. The end of the rope would initially lag behind, yes, but over time it will catch up and be more uniform with the rest of the rope, stabilizing in a straight line.

I originally picked E because the rotor would cause high pressure near the helicopter, and the farther it gets from the aircraft the less the effect would be.

Then i read a comment saying "a constant speed includes stationary flight" and changed my answer to A, thinking it was a trick question. Including that movement to the right is key!

Hey Derek! Thanks so much for sharing this riddle and the experimental check. I agree with your explanation, though I'd like to point one missing detail from it. You use the fact that the air friction is constant along the rope, but that's only true for a straight rope. Otherwise, the friction should change with the slope - it should be maximal for a vertical piece and minimal for a horizontal piece. So the configuration from B is a solution to the equation of motion, but you still need to show that there is no other configuration (achievable from other initial conditions). In fact, that's what I spent half of my working day on when you posted the original quiz :D

I actually balanced out the forces and tried to solve it multiple time, but always had too many free variables. While your explanation is intuitively correct, your force diagram is not. Every infinitesimally small rope section is also subject to the tension created by the all the rope sections beneath it. Those tension forces are not necessarily colliniear, at least I haven't been able to prove it mathematically.
F + T1 * cos a = T2 * cos b
Mg + T1 * sin a = T2 * sin b

T1,T2 - the tension force to the lower/upper rope section
a,b - angles between x axis / horizontal and tension forces
F - force imparted due to wind
Mg - section mass times gravity

Yay I got it correctly! This is quite a fun physics riddle.

Also I guess the "cross section is the same" argument is kind of the the result, not the reason. I did the calculation when the post was published and I got the following integral equality (which I put in the comment under the post back then)

tan(θ(x)) = [κ * ∫<from 0 to x>(cos(θ(x')) * d(x'))] / (ρ * g * x).

where θ(x) is the angle between the rope and the normal line to a horizontal plane at the point x on the rope (with x = 0 is the tip of it); κ is the air resistance coefficient (proportional to speed) and ρ is the linear density of the rope. The only solution I can find is

θ(x) = arcsin(sqrt((1 / α)^2 + 1) - 1 / α) = constant, with α = 2 * κ / (ρ * g).

Since θ(x) is constant, the rope forms a straight line. Moreover, taking the limit of speed -> 0+ yields θ(x) -> 0 (hanging straight down when hovering), and the limit of speed -> ∞ yields sin(θ(x)) -> 1, or θ(x) -> π / 2 (a horizontal line under very fast speed).

Not a very rigorous question. Besides the obvious negligible rotor wash assumption that must be made, you also have to assume that air resistance is uniform along the rope (which it isn’t). The tip of the rope will have different aerodynamic characteristics than the rest of the rope. This doesn’t manifest itself into the shape of the rope changing at low speeds, but because the problem doesn’t specify an air speed, at really high air speeds I would imagine that the rope wouldn’t be straight. You also have to consider that at high air speeds, a straight rope might not be a stable configuration. If the rope were to slightly change shape, the air resistance at every point of the rope would be different. Again, this won’t manifest itself at slow velocities because the magnitude of gravity is much is greater than that the magnitude of air resistance on any point of the rope, but I imagine at high velocities some strange turbulent effects could find another equilibrium

The thing about this is that the devil is in the details.
What if the rope were infinetly light? What if it were infinetly heavy?
What if the prop wash were infinetly strong or more concentrated? What if the airspeed were infinetly strong or absent?

Ultimately, the answer lies in the middle of these bounding conditions. The fact is that several of the answers COULD be reasonably true depending on the circumstances that you constrain the problem quesiton with and exactly how idealized the model is. As a scientist, I understand the idealized model presented, but as an engineer, I also want to know what the boundries of the conditions might be.

So the right answer is "None of the above, without providing more information".

I grew up watching wildland fire fighters pick up buckets of water next to my house, so i knew it was D instantly without even thinking about it (with a weight on the rope). You rarely see a rope with no extra weight on the end at all flying, so i would argue that the answer is practically always D, and almost never B. Even when a bucket of water is dumped, the bucket weighs enough to form D. When a crane drops its load, the hook on the end of a cable (if the cable can't be retracted) will make it form D. Pretty much the only time you might ever see B is a few seconds before a rope is pulled back up into the helicopter. As i understand it, you don't want to fly with a dangling rope that has no weight on it at all for the reasons the pilot gave in this video.

All that considered, the question is a lot like asking "how does a car drive with it has 1,364 wheels on it?" Who cares? There is an answer but it is utterly useless, especially when held against reality which is often the point of studying physics.

This is actually not what I predicted, but there is more to consider.  There are two kinds of flow - laminar and turbulent.  If you are going to include air resistance, it's beyond the bounds of simple physics in my opinion.  At some point, the length and weight of the rope is going to have the possibility to transition from one to the other.  The calculation of when/if that transition will take place would be for true experts only, but having the question so generic ignores this possibility.

We can also explain all the correct answers in these 3 situations by balancing the torque. Like, in first situation, we have constant ratio of forces acting at every section of rope horizontally and vertically, to balance the torque, it must stay at such an angle whose tanθ is inverse of the ratio of these forces. Similarly, in second situation, ratio of forces is increasing on moving upwards, so tanθ must be decreasing to balance torque.

The original question can simply be understood by drawing the free body diagram considering the rope and the helicopter together as a system. The air resistance acts horizontally in the direction opposite to the motion of helicopter and gravity vertically downwards. The net effective acceleration or force would then be the vector sum of these two forces and its direction would determine the position of the rope.

I guess the confusion for most people comes from assuming the airflow has a significant downwards component due to the rotor of the heli. The reason why this isn't the case is because the heli needs to be as fuel efficient as possible and to do that it needs to accelerate the air as little as possible. This is because for the same applied force that is needed to hover the faster the air is accelerated, the more work the rotor does. That's why helicopters have such big blades. By spreading the force over more air you accelerate it less so you do less work.

You used, for various good reasons, a denser than usual rope. But it seems as if the shape would be different with a much lighter rope of the same diameter. It might also depend on using a length such that some of the rope is in the downwash and some isn't. In order to produce the same angle with a rope that had more drag versus mass, you'd fly slower, so the downwash would represent a larger component of the air velocity at the rope, presuming the rope was within the stream. I believe you'll find that downwash airspeed actually increases until a peak around 2 rotor diameters beneath the craft, or some similar figure. I could imagine carefully designing a scenario where the slope actually forms a S curve, if that's true.
Also, there's a reasonable chance that for some scales and some ropes there might be a non-negligible extra drag component at the tip of the rope? Probably less noticeable at large scale than small, by square-cube law or some other reason.

What if the cable was elastic?
If we split the cable in small parts like you did in 5:05, each part with the same length WILL NOT BE the same weight. The bits closer to the helicopter would have to support more weight, so they would stretch more than the bits at the end of the cable. What would be the shape then?

I know why most of us (myself included) guessed C for the answer.
That's because at the end of the rope, the weight is negligible, you only have the air resistance to contend with. You'd need to have some heavy rope as thick as someones forearm (such as the one used in this video) to get enough weight for the weight to matter at all in the first meter (the bottom first) of the rope length.

That's simply because we know if you hold a piece of string like that in the wind it's not going to hang down noticably, it's going to flutter about in the wind, sometimes pointing up, sometimes down according to the wind with the weight being so small that it matters only little.

So in conclusion I still believe there has to be for each given rope (aka each weight and drag coeficcient) a certain wind speed above which the purely diagonal direction changes into the case that looks a lot like the one with the parachute. And I think that has to do with the above section of the rope creating a windbreak for the section below.

"The way I came to answer is - since the acceleration is zero ideally (considering air resistance to be 0) will give answer A, but it is not the case. So air resistance formula is 0.5*A*Cd*rho*v^2. I was surprisingly right, but your explanation was kind of convoluted. Wouldn't it be simpler to examine the rope in terms of CoM, CoP and torques rather than segmented pieces that have different, unidirectional forces on them? The angle of the rope and the force on the rope don't seem inherently related at first glance from your explanation.

Also your explanation for the weight one seems wrong and inconsistent. The force of drag for the rope cannot increase as drag is a function of velocity (for this example). The entire rope is moving at the same speed so each of those "segments" undergoes the same amount of drag. This is an example where you have to use moments and torques. The CoM appears to have moved down below the CoP, meaning there are now torques on two different locations causing the bend we see.

Firstly a bad question. (I'm writing this at the 0:36 point in the video)
* "Flying horizontally" - Ok so it's moving on a 2 dimensional plane horizontal to the ground....
* "Flying through the air to the right" - I MUST infer there is an implied "To the normal direction of travel which would be forward". An English major could better explain why "Flying through the air to the right" is not the same as "Flying through the air as VIEWED FROM THE right"
Then they show 5 pictures all with the view point on the starboard side of the helicopter looking at the helicopter.
So reading the paper and looking at the picture, the helicopter is flying sideways towards me. This makes me think A, as any curve due to the motion of travel (alone) would be within the vertical plane that I'm looking, aka it would be curved AWAY from me.
If I was infront of the helicopter I could see B,C,D or E, but as the image shows I'm off to the side that detail would not be evident.
Assuming the main rotar is spinning on a clockwise manner (when looking from the top down), I'd say D due to the rotar (rotar wash) causing the air to spiral down.

Answering the question as I think it was intended then as the helicopter approached a higher and higher speed my answer would be "D" a perfectly flexible uniform (I infer mass as well as thickness). depending on the method of attaching E could also be a contender. D is a knot or loop that is connected to a point which is free to pivot eg a bowline on an eye. E is a more rigid connection. If the helicopter is moving slower than walking speed then it would be A

Rotor wash does not dissipate "pretty quickly"!  It is defined to have a huge affect upon the helicopter's performance to the width of the rotor system BELOW the helicopter, and in this helicopter's case, almost 11 meters, and it is cone shaped inward toward the rope where it is probably accelerating on the way.  It certainly is still effective upon the rope at 15 meters, easy.  The only way to leave that cone is to go beyond Effective Translational Lift airspeed (16-24 knots), where you outrun the downward flowing air.  That would be a brave pilot though. An interesting way to look at the problem: discrete approximation of continuity

Imagine weightless rope with weight at bottom. Straight line, simple case.
Now half the weight is at middle point, other haf stays at bottom. Still straight line, can solve analytically.
Now a quarter of the weight is at bottom, another at quarter point, then at middle, then at 3/4 rope. Still straight line, analytic solution twice as tedious.
As step number n approches infinity, weight distribution approaches uniform distribution. In other words, reality. Still straight line.

Note: That straight line can be vertical or diagonal, doesn't matter. Even diagonal forward, if its a magical helium rope.

This is the kind of question that is really ambiguous and there's really no real answer to it. If the cable has enough air friction and it's long enough to the point where the tension is unable to keep it straight, it might form a J shape (answer C). If the helicopter is moving at a low speed and the cable is heavy enough, it might form a reversed J shape (answer D). There are simply too many open-end variables to the question. If you answer B/C/D you pass the question IMO.

11:00 This doesn't explain why the ratio of Fa/Fg as you climb the rope is not linear as in the weightless example -- thereby maintaining a horizontal rope all the way from one end to the other. The answer is that as you begin climbing from the far end with the parachute, the differential increase of air resistance starts off negligibly compared to the constant increase in weight due to horizontal arrangement in the rope reducing drag. As you climb higher, the increase in weight compared to the negligible increase in resistance points the tension upward, thereby increasing drag as you climb higher until their rate of increase for weight and resistance equalizes. The explanation presented for the linear rope makes sense if the rope is weightless, but it isn't. The tensions shouldn't be identical at all points on the rope because the top of the rope has to carry the weight of the rope bellow it. If that extra downward force were canceled out by increased air resistance that would make sense... but there's no way there could be a difference in friction if the rope is linear and moving at a constant speed. Air resistance is a function of the cross sectional surface of the object and it's speed, and if the rope is linear then every point on the rope has an identical friction force applied to it.

They have effectively looked at the rope like they did with the flag experiment, except they concluded that it is linear instead of figuring that it's just not noticably curved. I think this is a classic case of knowing the answer you want ahead of time and framing the video around that second, rather than doing an actual rigourus experiment.

I think most people chose C because they assumed the rope would’ve been in a fixed position pointing perpendicular to the aircraft and ground and not on a pivot like shown in Dereks explanation and experiment. The ability for the rope to pivot at it starting point from the aircraft gives the rope the straight diagonal representation. A rope with any amount of stiffness with its starting point being fixed at perpendicular to the ground and aircraft would result in option C, this can more easily be imagined with stiffer shorter rope travelling at a high speed where the end of the rope will trail behind the fixed starting point resulting in a curved shape like option C. Overall it was a poorly defined question that, from the diagrams presented, suggested a fixed starting point. The correct answer is still 'E'. Due to the effect of air resistance and the distribution of weight, in order to maintain constant tension, the rope must have a curve of a sinusoidal shape, when accounting for the weight beneath it... The mean of the curve is still 'B', but the practical force being imparted is 'E'. One of the factors that isn't taken into account in the written question is how fast the helicopter is flying. Helicopters have two flight modes - one is hovering, one is high-speed flight, where it gets into what is called translational lift.

In the hovering mode, the airblast from the rotors is going down around the helicopter. In high-speed flight mode, the downwash from the rotors goes down behind the helicopter, more like on an aircraft with wings.

A rope hanging beneath a helicopter that is mostly hovering will be blown about differently than a rope beneath a helicopter that is moving fast.

Many readers assume one or the other.

There is so much wrong with this. I am part of the ~1% who disliked this video, so I am clearly in the minority and this one of the (at the time of writing) more than 2,000 comments, but I think I am right. So here are my points:

1. If the question is so counter-intuitive, that the questioner himself calls it that way, and then goes on to say, that if he modifies it slightly, it gets even more counter-intuitive, it is a bad exam-question.

2. I did not see a straight rope, I saw a wiggly rope. The experiment had too many variables to be conclusive. Yes, this video must fit the YouTube-format, but in this case it was at the expanse of accuracy. I say, we can not draw conclusions from that.

3. "The rotor wash doesn't extend below the helicopter all that far." But it is not zero. So it bends the cable.

4. The gravity of the earth is "stronger" when closer to the surface and weaker higher in the sky. Meaning the lower part of the cable has a stronger gravitational pull, bending the cable (probably) slightly downwards. This is something, you would not see with this type of experiment. I guess it is hard to measure in the first place. But still, it is there, probably leading to a different answer.

But air is thinner the higher you go, which means lower air resistance. Therefore the answer is technically D.

Hm, I chose B for the first one and D for the latter one, kinda intuitively. Now I feel like a genius. The way I thought about it was for B, I imagined the rope would normally hang down, but when moving towards a direction, then the upper end would be moving first and the low end last (just like ropes move in general when I try to pull them). Since I couldn't find a reason for why the air resistance would be different at any part of the rope, it seemed like whichever force acting on it would be constant, so I chose B. For D again, I chose intuitively. If there's a weight on the thing then it must do something to the rope; it can't just be ignored, that wouldn't make sense, as gravity still exists. So it was between B and D. Intuitively I thought the rope would have to act similarly to a sail - since it's attached on the top end, and the weight makes it pseudo-attached on the bottom end, it's like a flag or a sail that is fixed at the top and where you're holding the bottom. The wind would blow evenly from the front, but the rope wouldn't like to bend so much the closer it is to the fix points and so the middle would be bending the most while the outer parts would become more stiff. So I chose D.
I might not have had the correct explanation for the physics, but I guess I intuitively thought of this like a sail or flag, so I'm kinda proud (and surprised!) I got the right answer in both cases :D

For math geeks out there, it's just parametric eqns.
theta(f,g)=arctan(f(x)/g(x))
Theta(f,g)=angle between tangent of rope with vertical line as a function for drag and weight
f(x)=Drag as a function of distance x
g(x)=Weight as a function of distance x
x=distance from bottom of rope

Without load:
f(x)=a*x (where a is a constant accounting for components of drag ==> air density, velocity, coefficient of drag, area viewed from front, etc)
g(x)=b*x (where b is a constant accounting for components of weight ==> density of rope, cross sectional area of rope and g)
Rearraging theta=arctan(f(x)/g(x)), theta=arctan((a*x)/(b*x)), theta=arctan(a/b)
Remember that a and b are constants ==> arctan(a/b)=constant ==> theta=constant ==> straight rope.

With weight:
All is same except g(x)=b*x+c (where c is the weight of mass added, also a constant)
Plot arctan((a*x)/(b*x+c)) and you'll see that at x=0, theta=0 and as x approaches infinity, theta converges to a constant value.
Meaning, at places very close the weight end, the rope is vertical but slowly turns into a straight diagonal line as it approaches the helicopter.

With parachute:
All is same except f(x)=b*x+d (where d is the drag of parachute added, also a constant)
Plot arctan((a*x+d)/(b*x)) and you'll see that at x=0, theta=arctan(d/0) ==> theta=90deg and as x approaches infinity, theta converges to a constant value.
Meaning at at places very close the parachute end, the rope is horizontal but slowly turns into a straight diagonal line as it approaches the helicopter.

What about this:
If i use linear density, both gravity component (vertical) and air resistence component (horizontal) depend only by the lenght "L" of the rope and linearly, same with the resultant. So we have a linear function (derivate constant =costant tangent = straight line).
The weight or the parachute add a constant "c" on one of the directions, so the resultant (sqrt of the sum of their squares) has one component with L^2 and one with (L+c)^2 which is not linear anymore unless L is way bigger than c (distant from the weight/drag).

The same situation as C with the cable hanging like a J happens with in air refueling of some jets and helicopters. Some use fuel lines with conical conectors which have less weight, since they have a more weight saving design than the rest of the lines and more drag, since their design is larger than the rest of the fuel line (to make it easier to connect). the effect is very subtle due to the high speeds but it still noticable sometimes.

In the absence of rotor downwash the answer is clearly B.  But, that is not what I picked. I tried to account for rotor downwash. I forgot that near the ground downwash feels very strong, but that is a ground effect. The same ground effect that keeps a hovercraft above the ground. At altitude rotor downwash dissipates very quickly because of the balance of pressure between the weight of the helicopter and the aerodynamics of the moving rotor.

As a physics major, I can say that while this may be a fair question to put on a test, I don’t think it’s a good one. While a lot of conceptual questions (not calculation based) are meant to by counterintuitive/tricky, the student should be able to arrive at the answer through identifying the basic forces and principles involved. However this question asks a lot of the student, it forces them to make assumptions that they wouldn’t be familiar making; it doesn’t really focus on the true intent/spirit of the testing material or testing for knowledge. Assuming a student to just know that the rotor wash is negligible is not really fair, especially in a conceptual (not calculation) based question like this.

Before watching the video, my guess is C: the wind force should be constant along the entire line (roughly), but the counteracting moment due to gravity will increase from the bottom of the line to the top. That means the end of the line should lag behind the top since at the bottom there's essentially nothing stopping the wind from blowing it back, but at the top, there's more counteracting moment to cause the rope to correct itself with regards to gravity.
HOWEVER, this will change based on speed - at some point gravity will be insignificant and you'll get B, and I'm not accounting for the downforce of wind due to the helicopter blades >.>...

Who here remembers a discussion somewhere about "kring"?

The idea is, if you fly a kite, the string will sag. If you add a second kite in the middle of the string, you'll get two smaller sags - but you and the two kites will define a straight line if the wind is uniform. Keep adding kites and the resulting sag will approximate the same straight line. Eventually, when you have an infinite number of kites, you will have a "kring" that flies in a straight line in uniform wind.

That's how I got the right answer in the quiz. :-)

actually there are lots of things shape (deformation) of the cable depends on: stiffness/mass characteristics of the cable; helicopter speed; cross-sectional form of the cable. For instance, on pretty high speeds there will be transition from quasi-static regime (low Strouhal number) to self-ocsillations. The fact that you were able to produce one answer doesn't mean it's the right answer (especially if you modify the parameters a bit - like you did). It says that it's not impossible to get that answer.
Let's say I spin around holding a rope. If I spin around slow enough, the shape I will get seen from the top will look like a vortex. If I spin fast enough the rope will fully extend producing a (nearly) straight line. Which one would be the answer to that question then?

The way this question is stated is problematic in many ways and depending how you interpret it may have multiple answers.
First - the way the helicopter is drawn is problematic, cause it may suggest a very small (yet constant - as the question stated) speed. That would produce the answer A to be the closest and you would find a neat equation to explain why that is (one where the gravity and the force downward produced by the roters are so strong that they force the rope staight down).
At certain speed and other parameters (leaving asside how those constant angle/speed adjustments by the pilot were creating the environment close to the one in the question) you were able to produce the answer B and found an explanation why that is. But that already resulted in two answers being correct. I don't have a helicopter nor the budget to rent one so I can't create and test more scenarios to see if at certain conditions the answer would change. The experience of the pilot may give us a hint though since he was worried that the end of the rope could bounce back to the helicopter's roters - so maybe C or even E are possible if the parameters - like the speed of the helicopter compared to the power downwards and air resistance were big enough.

Seems like the pilot did pay attention and made constant adjustments and decisions for a reason. If the answer would be a clear B, that wouldn't be a problem until you'd reach the level of the line being close to horizontal.
That's the problem of the question and in part of this video giving up too quickly - you found an answer, made sure that it fit the criteria of the question and was sound and ended at it. Worked backwards from one answer. You can prove a lot of things like that which aren't always true in a broader picture. In questions like this you have to make sure that there's only one correct answer if you expect the one you ended up with to be correct.

Any good pedant would take issue with the language of the question; the question is ambiguous, given the answer choices.

0:18 "Which of the following diagrams shows the shape of the cable as the helicopter flies through the air to the right?"

None of the diagrams show the helicopter flying to its right. The question needs to say its right, not the right, to be properly specific. As it is, the reader does not know with certainty what is meant by the question and can only surmise, from the answer choices, what is meant. Even a two-bit lawyer would scoff at this question.

This is why in theater, a director will say stage right (or house left), and in film, he'll say camera right (or scene/frame left).

Even physicists — or dare I say especially physicists? — need precision of language. Language precision is not just for grammarians and lawyers.

The reason why i chose B is, I'm not like a science student with college degree but i am taking physics, chemistry, math, english, computer etc. That doesn't matter but B seemed to be more logical because if you ever played with kites before, You notice that the kite would need to be in a certain position to have an constant air flow in it and in a way that it starts to lift of with the respect of the string you are carrying with. So my idea was that i've noticed that the middle and the end of the string away from my hand would always move around because it has an thin string and the amount of air hitting the kite would make it lift off. I applied the same situation here but with a twist because i already knew when he said rope, It has to be soo thick that regular person can't normal use it. So it was obvious to me that the rope should be made out of nylons and stuff like that. The tension in nylon is great and can bend too, If we apply the same kite concept here, We use the help of kite to make the thin string move around in straight line than bending, except since there is already good air resistance and they say it's a rope so there has got to be a very good amount of surface area covering up in the air with the respect of the length shown in the diagram, when you are flying in a helicopter, It would totally make sense to be in the straight line as the rope is following the path of the helicopter resulting more air resistance hitting on  it in the other direction from it's path, It would need to hit it equally and the by the law of physics, Each molecules/object etc would have the same amount of gravitational forces pulling towards the earth, Further away from earth results lesser gravitational pull but helicopters just fly few thousand feet above the ground so it wouldn't matter much and if you keep adding up the vectors of air resistance vs the gravitational pull, It would obviously show a diagonal line. But since helicopters can't be flying at the same constant speed or atleast in this case because he is checking at the rope while driving so I'm sure maintaining the same proper speed is impossible and in this case they show different results in the movement at the bottom of the rope. Maybe i might sound bit too nerdy but i just assumed the rope to be something like strong nylon as it made sense to follow one of the diagrams given by.

Something else explains the curvature and that the tension changes magnitude and direction the way it does.

I feel like the case of a parachute at the end of the rope (making a horizontal to steepening curve) is the most intuitive, and turning the parachute into a weight (making a vertical to less steep curve) helps make the weighted case more intuitive. I wrote a long comment explaining my interpretation, but sometimes my comments don't get noticed at all. Even though mine was posted a short while after the video.

Basically, I said that the drag force on the wire was constant along its length (because the heli has a const velocity) but because it is free at one end, there will be a gradient of torque on the wire due to that force. Max torque at the free end, 0 at the pivot (heli) of course. This will create a nice straight line.

Derek I don’t think this analysis fully answers the question. I believe the question is fundamentally unanswerable without knowing the ratio between the weight of the helicopter and its forward air speed. Imagine a scenario where the helicopter weighs 100,000 lbs, requiring 100,000 lbs of lift, and a forward air speed of only 10 mph. The downwash required to hold a 100,000 lb helicopter in steady level flight will surely overpower the drag created by the 10mph forward air speed, and will dominate any analysis of the system. Now imagine the inverse, a 50 lb helicopter drone with a forward air speed of 100mph. With this ratio, the downwash created by 50lbs of lift will be totally negligible relative to the drag created by a 100mph air speed.

A ignores the air friction. Wrong.

C and D are instances just before / after the copter acceleration is at 0 repsectively. Velocity is not constant. Wrong.

E is stupid.

B is the answer. There are 2 forces: Gravity and friction due to wind. Gravity pulls down, friction pulls uniformally horizontally. Two orthoganal vectors summed make a diagonal net vector.

There exists another extreme where the copter is in space (abd somehow works). In that instance, gravity and air has no influence on the rope, making it drag behind horizontally.

A smaller weight will not change the direction of the curve, but only makes the curvature lower.)

I’m just gonna paste my solution from the last post here. I have not watched this video and I’m hoping that I’d at least be partially correct.

“I really think it must be D.

Consider all the forces acting upon a segment of the rope in the middle. There is gravity dragging it downwards, and also the wind blowing it to the right. Together, these two forces combined should be pointing downwards and to the left.

There is also tension dragging it right and up and tension dragging it left and down. Since the rope is flexible, the magnitude of the two tension must be identical. However, because the rope may not be straight, the combined tension should point inwards perpendicular to the tangent line of the arch.

Since every bit of the rope is moving at a constant speed, the total force acting on this segment must be zero. Therefore, the combined tension must be pointing downwards to the right, so is the direction that the rope curves towards.”
